action.action-desc: Mr. Sam Johnson of Texas (for himself and Mr. Larson of Connecticut) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means

form.official-title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to exclude from income discharge of medical indebtedness.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Medical Debt Tax Relief Act.

section.header: Exclusion of discharge of medical indebtedness

subsection.text: Section 108 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (a)(1), by striking or in subparagraph (D), by striking the period at the end of subparagraph (E) and inserting , or, and by adding at the end the following new subparagraph:

subparagraph.text: the indebtedness discharged is qualified medical indebtedness.

paragraph.text: by adding at the end the following new subsection:
For purposes of this section, the term qualified medical indebtedness means indebtedness which was incurred by an individual for—

subparagraph.text: diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease of the taxpayer or the spouse or a dependent of the taxpayer, or for the purpose of affecting any structure or function of the body of the taxpayer or the spouse or a dependent of the taxpayer,
for transportation primarily for and essential to medical care referred to in subparagraph (A), or
for qualified long-term care services for the taxpayer or the spouse or a dependent of the taxpayer.

paragraph.text: Rules similar to the rules of paragraphs (2), (5), (8), (9), and (11) of section 213(d) shall apply for purposes of this subsection.
For purposes of this subsection, any term also used in section 213(d)(1) shall have the same meaning as when used in such section.

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply with respect to indebtedness discharged after the date of enactment of this Act.
